name: Slate & Stone Tonal
usage_rules: Use slate as the dominant surface color on stationery
Stone as a secondary on linens and signage backgrounds
Pale grey reserved for negative space and paper stock
Avoid introducing warm undertones — keep all applications strictly cool

name: Platinum & Charcoal
usage_rules: Charcoal anchors typography and hard surface materials
Platinum applies to foil accents and metal hardware
Near-white reserved for paper stock and linen
High formality — do not pair with rustic or organic textures

compatibility.notes: Black Tie or Architectural Minimal; requires formality ≥3

name: Dusty Blue & Ivory
usage_rules: Dusty blue leads on florals, stationery headers, and accent linens
Ivory grounds tablescapes and ceremony backdrops
Deep teal used sparingly as an anchor in signage only
Avoid bright white — always use warm ivory as the neutral base

compatibility.notes: Soft blue-ivory; pairs with balanced or organic shapes

name: Midnight & Cobalt
usage_rules: Midnight as the dominant dark ground — stationery, signage, linens
Cobalt applied as a bold accent: foil, florals, graphic elements
Near-white used only for typography on dark grounds
This is a high-contrast palette — commit fully or it reads muddled

name: Cream & Terracotta Tonal
usage_rules: Cream as the primary background for all print and linen applications
Terracotta used as a punctuation color — florals, wax seals, ribbon
Brown-taupe grounds ceramics and natural fiber materials
Avoid introducing cool tones — all applications stay within the warm register

name: Ochre & Sage
usage_rules: Ochre as the lead color for florals and print accents
Sage applied to foliage, linen, and secondary signage
Warm linen as the neutral base for all surfaces
Earthy and grounded — avoid any cool or metallic accents

compatibility.notes: Earthy Textural Warmth; low formality variant

name: Blush & Antique Rose
usage_rules: Blush dominates soft surfaces — paper, linen, ceremony florals
Antique rose deepens florals and provides visual anchor
Off-white cream grounds typography and negative space
Pairs beautifully with warm brass and aged gold metal accents

name: Saffron & Burgundy
usage_rules: Saffron leads on florals and graphic accent elements
Burgundy anchors dark grounds and dramatic signage
Warm cream reserved for paper and light typography
High energy — confident commitment required; do not dilute with grey

name: Ivory & Warm Taupe
usage_rules: Ivory anchors all paper and linen surfaces
Taupe provides depth on signage and secondary surfaces
Warm grey grounds without introducing temperature
Universal foundation palette — pairs with any metal temperature

compatibility.notes: Versatile neutral base; works across all formality levels

name: Warm White & Graphite
usage_rules: Warm white as primary background across all applications
Graphite for typography, rule lines, and hardware
Mid-grey softens transitions between light and dark elements
Clean and modern — avoids the coldness of pure black and white

compatibility.notes: Refined neutral for balanced or architectural shapes

name: Ink & Acid Green
usage_rules: Ink as the dominant ground — bold, editorial, uncompromising
Acid green as the singular accent color — florals, type, seals
Near-white for any reversed typography only
Bold Graphic Editorial territory — must commit to the contrast

name: Deep Jewel & Champagne
usage_rules: Deep jewel dominates ceremony and reception linens
Purple accent applied to florals and foil details
Champagne reserved for paper stock and metal hardware only
Formal and dramatic — suited to evening or candlelit settings

compatibility.notes: Refined Black Tie jewel variant; high formality required
